Legal_Issue: Did the visa officer breach procedural fairness by not accepting the statutory declaration as proof of the applicant's brother's residency in Canada?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Statutory declaration was provided but deemed insufficient; only objective third-party evidence accepted
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to prove residency with required documentation
Credibility_Factor: No issue of credibility raised; focus on admissibility of evidence type
Legal_Rule: Visa officers must follow IRPA and Regulations; procedural fairness requires clear communication but not reconsideration without bad faith
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to accept statutory declaration as proof of residency
Review_Standard: Procedural fairness, fettering of discretion, duty to reconsider
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No breach found; clear instructions given and no bad faith shown
Applicant_Challenge: Visa officerâ€™s refusal to accept statutory declaration as valid proof
Legal_Rule_Source: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Maintained requirement for objective third-party evidence; followed regulatory requirements
Evidence_Type: Statutory declaration (self-declared), lack of third-party objective evidence
Legal_Provision: Sections of Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and associated Regulations regarding residency proof
Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient proof of familial residency in Canada
Pending_Relief_or_Application: None indicated; case concluded with denial
Governing_Rule: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations requiring objective evidence for residency
